metadata.title: Peripheral Artery Disease and Exercise
synonyms: lower extremity vascular occlusive disease and exercise
atherosclerotic peripheral vascular disease and exercise
anatomical location body part affected: Commonly the abdominal aorta, pelvic, femoral, and tibial arteries; usually affects muscles (often the calf) of the lower extremity
description: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is a disease in which occlusive atherosclerotic lesions develop in the extremities, and is a manifestation of a systemic atherosclerotic process(19)
Arterial stenosis causes inadequate blood flow in distal limbs and results in the failure to meet metabolic demands during exertion(17)
In the lower extremities (LE), lesions tend to occur in three anatomic segments: the aortoiliac segment, femoral-popliteal segment, and the infrapopliteal or tibial segment of the arterial tree(19)
Patients with PAD should receive a program ofstructured exercise and lifestyle modification, as it reduces cardiovascular ischemic events and improves functional status(16)
Supervised treadmill exercise is recommended as the first line of therapy for walking impairment in PAD(25)

Research has shown that exercise is important in treating PAD because it leads to decreased leg pain and improvement in general physical condition, but itsinfluence onQOL is not as clear,(4) although authors of a 2017 review stated that QOL is improved with exercise(26)

The 2016 American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelinesstate that research is needed to identify the best community-or  home-based  exercise programs for patients with PAD to maximize functional status and improve QOL. Also, there a need to investigate the role of such exercise programs before or in addition to revascularization(16)

Relevant definitions –Claudication -Pain in the calf of one or both legs that occurs during walking and is relieved only by rest(4) –Acute arterial occlusion of a limb(16,19) -Rapid or sudden decrease in limb perfusion that threatens tissue viability -Might be due to an embolus or to thrombosis of a diseased atherosclerotic segment -Symptoms include pain, paralysis, pulselessness, mottling, and pallor  -Vascular emergency; immediate revascularization is required within 3 hours; by 6 hours, irreversible tissue damage is guaranteed –Critical limb ischemia(16,19) -Defined by most vascular clinicians as lower extremity chronic ischemic rest pain, ulceration, or gangrene attributable to arterial occlusive disease -Chronic resting perfusion defect leads to the inability to adequately supply blood to sustain viability of the extremity -Bypass grafting is the primary technique of revascularization -Associated with the highest rate of amputation –Intermittent claudication (IC): transient leg pain due to poor circulation
Patients with PAD often report the onset of IC typically in the calf muscles first and during physical activity(19)
Claudication pain promotes sedentary behavior and thus decreases physical functioning in ADLs as well as activity-related QOL(27)

Diagnostic ultrasound measurement of the ankle-brachial  index (ABI) is the most often used clinical tool to assess PAD severity. ABI is assessed by obtaining BP at the ankle (dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries) and both brachial arteries while patient is supine and limb is at same position as heart. The higher of the two ankle pressures is then divided by the higher of the two brachial pressures to determine the ABI(17,18)
ABI ≥ 1.40 – noncompressible calcified vessel – can try toe-brachial index instead
ABI 0.91–0.99  borderline PAD, consider additional testing
ABU ≤0.90, abnormal and diagnostic for PAD
Leg segmental pressures can also be done to determine where occlusion is – a drop of 20mm Hg is considered significant

Exercise training has been found to improve cardiorespiratory fitness, pain-free  and total flat-ground  walking distance, and graded treadmill performance in patients with PAD.(25) This Clinical Review  highlights the prominent role of supervised exercise therapy for the medical management of lower-extremity  PAD in patients with IC
For further information, see Clinical Review…Peripheral Artery Disease (P AD) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708878, and Clinical Review…Angina Pectoris, Stable ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708896

reimbursement: CPT code 93668 was approved in 2001 for programs that address supervised exercise programs for physical therapists (PTs) treating patients with PAD; however, some medical insurance companies might not cover  supervised treadmill exercise training. In 2017, the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) in the United States decided to provide coverage for 36 sessions of supervised treadmill exercise over 12 weeks for patients with PAD(25) –The CMS program requires that exercise training be held in a hospital outpatient setting or a physician’s office, be conducted by qualified personnel trained in advanced life support techniques, and that the patient first meets with the doctor to receive information about cardiovascular disease risk and risk-factor  reduction –An additional 36 sessions can be covered by CMS if approved

Presentation/signs and symptoms –Patient may be in one of four categories of PAD:(27) -asymptomatic -IC – activity causes aching pain in calves or buttocks that is relieved with rest – about 25% of patients and is usually stable -chronic limb ischemia (CLI) – pain at rest or ulceration with or without tissue necrosis –generally requires amputation -acute limb ischemia (ALI) – rapid onset of claudication quickly resulting in pain at rest –emergency -Results in “the six P’s” – pain, pulselessness, pallor, poikilothermia, paresthesia, paralysis -Patients might present with a history of chronic and reproducible activity-related  IC -Described as burning, heaviness/deep fatigue, and/or cramping in the legs -Onset often begins in the calf muscles -Bilateral or unilateral -Pain might extend to proximal leg muscles (thigh and buttock) in severe cases -Pain is relieved by slowing or stopping the activity -Present in only 10–30%  of patients with PAD;(17) in fact, the American Heart Association estimates that 75% of the 8.5 million Americans with PAD are asymptomatic(18) -The intensity of IC pain typically increases with the intensity/speed and distance of leg exercise such as walking or cycling -Weak lower extremity pulses and ABI≤90 -Patient might also present with resting leg pain,(17) non-healing  wounds,(17,18) and impotence/erectile dysfunction(17,19) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
presentation signs and symptoms: –Patient may be in one of four categories of PAD:(27) -asymptomatic -IC – activity causes aching pain in calves or buttocks that is relieved with rest – about 25% of patients and is usually stable -chronic limb ischemia (CLI) – pain at rest or ulceration with or without tissue necrosis –generally requires amputation -acute limb ischemia (ALI) – rapid onset of claudication quickly resulting in pain at rest –emergency -Results in “the six P’s” – pain, pulselessness, pallor, poikilothermia, paresthesia, paralysis -Patients might present with a history of chronic and reproducible activity-related  IC -Described as burning, heaviness/deep fatigue, and/or cramping in the legs -Onset often begins in the calf muscles -Bilateral or unilateral -Pain might extend to proximal leg muscles (thigh and buttock) in severe cases -Pain is relieved by slowing or stopping the activity -Present in only 10–30%  of patients with PAD;(17) in fact, the American Heart Association estimates that 75% of the 8.5 million Americans with PAD are asymptomatic(18) -The intensity of IC pain typically increases with the intensity/speed and distance of leg exercise such as walking or cycling -Weak lower extremity pulses and ABI≤90 -Patient might also present with resting leg pain,(17) non-healing  wounds,(17,18) and impotence/erectile dysfunction(17,19) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Consult physician regarding signs/symptoms of DVT if patient has a painful, swollen calf and/or a red, warm calf and resume exercises only when physician clears patient
Obtain physician order for restrictions on exercise if chronic DVT is present
Consult physician if nonhealing wounds are present
Screen patient for other symptoms that might limit exercise tolerance, such as foot pathology, non-healing  LE wounds, arthritis, chest pain, and shortness of breath
Stop the exam if patient complains of chest pain, shortness of breath, abnormal fatigue, or dizziness
In many cases, physician clearance and supervision are required for exercise testing

causes: Atherosclerosis: most common cause–usually most advanced in the iliac arteries and lower extremities. Patients with PAD might also have associated coronaryartery disease (CAD) or carotid artery disease
pathogenesis: In patients with PAD, arterial stenosis causes inadequate blood flow in distal limbs and failure to meet the metabolicdemand during exercise(17)
The degree of ischemia is proportional to the size and proximity of the occlusion to the end organ(17)
Acidic products of anaerobic metabolism build up within the muscle and result in claudication clinically(17)
Arterial occlusion also causes significantly diminished distal pressure in patients with PAD due to atheroscleroticlesions(17)

Plaque formation in PAD restricts the increase in arterial flow needed to supply the greater limb oxygen (O 2) demand ofexercise. Consequently, O 2 supply to the affected limb can become insufficient, resulting in IC

IC begins with the occurrence of muscle tissue anoxia and accumulation of metabolic products of anaerobiosis (e.g., lacticacid) and subsides after exercise as the O 2 supply-demand balance is restored

Although ABI screening increases the frequency of PAD diagnosis compared to history and physical exam, symptomsmight not be evident at rest even when ABI ≤ 0.9. Exercise is the usual factor that triggers IC and the awareness of PAD(26)
Objective testing for IC includes walking tolerance time (speed and distance) on a treadmill and the 6-minute  walk test(6MWT) for distance at a self-selected  speed

In a study conducted in the United States of 384 men and women with ABI ≤0.90 followed for a median of 47 months,patients with greater sedentary hours per day and slower outdoor walking speed showed faster declines in walking speed(assessed by the 6MWT) and reduced calf muscle mass(1)
Supervised exercise training is an important component of medical management for increasing the time until IC onset andfor improving walking speed, walking distance, and quality of life(16,26)

During the last several decades, researchers have developed a better understanding of the contribution of inflammation tothe pathophysiological mechanism of PAD–Researchers who conducted a study in the United States found an association between systemic inflammation andimpairment of walking time in patients with PAD and IC, but further studies are needed to understand how this and othernonhemodynamic factors contribute to IC and to drive the development of new therapies(9)

The endothelium plays a crucial role in vascular homeostasis.Endothelial dysfunction might play a part in the developmentof PAD, as it might express pro-inflammatory  and pro-thrombotic  features, activate oxidative reactions, and stimulate aproliferative state. The general health of the endothelium is influenced by such factors as medications, diet, and physicalactivity(11)

In addition to pharmacotherapy to reduce IC, medical intervention is aimed at prevention of atherosclerosis and thereforeincludes treatment (e.g., statins, antihypertensive medications) for existing atherogenic risk factors
risk factors: Conventional atherogenic risk factors (e.g., hypertension, elevated serum lipids, diabetes, physical inactivity, cigarettesmoking, and obesity) are associated with the etiology of PAD(12,17,18)–African American ethnicity is a strong and independent risk factor for PAD(18)

Based on a cross-sectional  study of 6,450 persons over 55 years of age, the following factors are implicated(2)–Current or former cigarette smoking: a common trait in PAD–Diabetes mellitus–Elevated fibrinogen level–Low high-density  lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol–Elevated systolic blood pressure (BP)–Age over 75 years–Family history of PAD, heart disease, or stroke
Other risk factors: chronic kidney disease(12,18)and hyperhomocysteinemia(17,18)

overall contraindications precautions: Obtain physician clearance for patient to participate in individualized exercise training program; adhere to any parameters set by the physician for vitals and exercise intensity
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with or without critical limb ischemia contraindicates exercise
ALI is a medical emergency and any patient suspected of having this (see symptoms listed above, under Description ) should be immediately referred to emergency services

Ischemic leg pain at rest is a relative contraindication to exercise. However, critical limb ischemia should be immediately ruled out (especially in patients with diabetes, neuropathy, chronic renal failure, or limb infection), as risk of amputation is high(59)
Multiple precautions might be warranted depending on any existing comorbidities, scope of disabilities, and weight-bearing restrictions from physician
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -What are the symptoms and when did they begin? What has been the general progression of symptoms since onset? -What modifiable risk factors are present? For example, does the patient smoke?(48) -Does the patient complain of leg pain at rest and/or during exercise? -Is physical activity restricted by IC? -Does the history indicate that walking ability has worsened?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management The two goals of PAD management are reducing symptoms, thereby improving quality of life, and reducing vascular morbidity and mortality(59) Have any complications, such as leg ulcers, thrombophlebitis, or gangrene, been treated? Document any treatments for atherogenic risk factor reduction and the patient’s compliance Conservative intervention What treatments have been tried for rehabilitation? Does the patient follow a physician-prescribed home exercise program? If so, is it helping function?
surgical management: Document any surgical/invasive interventions such as revascularization treatment (e.g., percutaneous transluminal angioplasty with/without stenting, bypass grafting)
For further information, see Clinical Review…Peripheral Artery Disease (P AD) , referenced above
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Determine what medications clinician has prescribed. Are they being taken and are they helping? Statins for lowering serum low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol(16) Antiplatelet drugs such as aspirin or clopidogrel for reducing intravascular clotting(16) ACE inhibitors for lowering BP. Treatment with ramipril is associated with improved walking tolerance time to onset of IC(16) Beta blocker for reducing myocardial ischemia if CAD is present Optimal glycemic control for patients with diabetes
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Less than or equal to 0.9 in repeated measures is common using Doppler method
Auscultatory method can be used, but the Doppler method is the gold standard
Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) and computed tomography angiography (CTA) are required only when symptoms require revascularization(19)
Physical examination includes:

Palpation of peripheral pulses, abdominal examination for aortic aneurysm, BP measured in both arms, auscultation for bruits in the neck and over the clavicles, abdomen and femoral pulses, assessment of skin temperature and color, and assessment of any wounds(16,18)
Duplex ultrasound(16,17)
Pulse volume recording(16,19)
Angiography  recommended in patients with critical limb ischemia and for patients being considered for revascularization(17)
Brachial artery flow-mediated endothelium-dependent  vasodilation (FMD) to assess arterial endothelial function (EF)(15)
Researchers who conducted a study in the United States found significant association between EF and disease severity as well as walking disability

Measures of FMD and nitroglycerin-induced vasodilation (NID) can be used to assess vascular reactivity, which researchers in Brazil found to be impaired and related to the severity of the PAD and to walking ability, as measured by 6MWT, in patients with intermittent claudication(21)
Diagnostic tests to rule out neurogenic causes and to assess tissue changes include spinal X-ray, MRI, CT, and electrodiagnostic testing(18)
Reliably measures the functional severity of IC
Considered a reasonable alternative to treadmill ABI testing for assessment of functional status
Distance walked at onset of leg pain is referred to as “claudication distance” or pain-free  distance, whereas maximum distance implies pain tolerance point
Treadmill exercise test(10,17)

Other tests that might be performed (possibly to identify modifiable risk factors) include serum glucose screening, fasting lipid profile,(17) and vitamin D levels (low levels have been associated with faster decline in functional measures in individuals with PAD)(5)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help Acupuncture, biofeedback, chelation therapy, and supplements such as gingko biloba, omega-3 fatty acids, and vitamin E have been studied(17)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Also inquire about cardiac or pulmonary rehabilitation treatment

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document factors (such as ambulation) that aggravate the patient’s symptoms. Are the symptoms relieved with rest?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms -Abdominal aorta  buttock -Iliac artery  hip/thigh -Superficial femoral artery and/or posterior and anterior tibial arteries  calf
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Claudication is most commonly described as deep fatigue, aching, or cramping pain
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). The onset and progression of exercise-related symptoms can be rated for perceived exertion (RPE) using the Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of times awakened at night. Patients with PAD typically have pain with ambulation and are not woken from pain at night; document any sleep pathology such as sleep apnea and current
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, symptoms of DVT)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient need supplemental oxygen? Are respiratory symptoms evident when walking? Is there a history of pulmonary embolism or any other respiratory compromise (e.g., emphysema or other COPD, especially if the patient is a smoker) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe __________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the patient had discomfort with ambulation in the past? Does patient have a history of any other arterial disease? History of nonhealing wounds?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including pulmonary disease, cardiovascular disease (CVD), diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders Researchers in Brazil found that CVD is associated with a lower total walking distance in patients with PAD, especially when clustered with hypertension and diabetes(6) In the presence of diabetes, PAD patients are at increased risk for disease progression to critical leg ischemia, LE amputation, and cardiovascular events(8) Researchers in the United States found that type 2 diabetes mellitus attenuated improvements in endothelial function, net plasma nitrate response, and painfree  walking time in patients with PAD compared to those without, following 3 months of exercise training(8) Researchers in the United States also found that women with PAD and diabetes respond particularly poorly to exercise rehabilitation(10)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about any other symptoms that can reduce physical activity

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational activities? Are there any activities that the patient enjoys and would like to be able to do that he or she cannot do at present due to PAD? Does the patient smoke or drink alcoholic beverages on a regular basis? Document the patient’s regular physical and occupational activities and if they involve walking (e.g., mail carrier)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Functional limitations include decreased ambulation distance. Sedentary behavior can lead to limitations in other ADLs secondary to weakness and decreased endurance. Ask the patient to specify limitations and any adaptive equipment used, including assistive devices
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Determine height, weight, and BMI –Determine whether the patient is overweight or obese and make recommendations for weight loss, if indicated
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient use a cane, walker, or other ambulatory device? Is the device properly fitted and being used correctly? Does the patient use any adaptive devices such as an elevated toilet seat or grab bars at home?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance. Fall risk might be assessed using Berg Balance Scale (BBS) or Tinetti test
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess vital signs, including pulse rate, BP, and respiratory rate
Administer 6MWT for claudication distance -At any time, patient might slow to relieve discomfort or stop the test due to intolerance -Note claudication distance (if unable to complete 6 minutes)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Circulation –Assess dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses(17)If indicated, assess body mechanics during occupational/ADL demands, while observing posture, efficiency, and safety. Document any IC occurring during occupational tasksDoes IC or other symptoms reduce functional mobility? If so, assess mobility using FIM and/or Timed Up and Go (TUG) test
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe for gait abnormalities or patterns that might reduce walking efficiency. As indicated, assess safety with Dynamic Gait Index (DGI). Maximum walking distance (MWD) is defined as the distance covered before limb pain or discomfort forces the patient to stop walking.(13) Maximum walking time (MWT) is defined as the amount of time  the patient can walk before onset of symptoms.(11) 10-meter  walk test (10MWT) can be used to assess walking speed over a short durationAssess joint mobility, as indicated. No joint abnormality is expected unless secondary pathology such as osteoarthritis is present
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess functional strength. Manual muscle testing might show weakness secondary to disuse atrophy in the affected limb
observation inspection palpation includi: Regularly inspect skin for any non-healing  wounds and closely monitor •Palpation: Check for bilateral differences in skin temperature of the legs/feet
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess for excessive trunk lean or obvious postural asymmetry that might affect posture during gaitDoes any disability interfere with self-care?  If so, document the problems, use Barthel Index for objective measure
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess flexibility and functional ROM of the lower extremities. Decreased physical activity, muscle shortening, and secondary pathologies might affect lower extremity flexibility
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess proprioception and skin sensation to light touch, deep pressure, two-point  discrimination, and temperature, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –PAD QOL Questionnaire –Clinical features suggestive of PAD -Weak or absent pedal pulse -Unilateral coolness of extremity -Prolonged venous filling time -Femoral or iliac artery bruit -Positive Buerger test (increased pain on hanging affected leg over side of bed) –Clinical features that are helpful but not specific for diagnosis of PAD -Capillary refill test -Foot discoloration -Atrophic skin -Hairless extremities -Warm knees –SF-36 –SF-12(14) –Walking Estimated-Limitation  Calculated by History (WELCH)(7) –WIQ(14)

other: DVT, critical limb ischemia, and other comorbidities that increase cardiovascular risk should be cleared by physician before beginning exercise activity

Electrotherapeutic modalities are not indicated for PAD, but check on contraindications/precautions for use of modalities for other musculoskeletal problems, including osteoarthritis, as might be indicated

Patients with PAD/IC might be at increased risk for falls. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. If applicable, discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: PAD/impaired walking speed and endurance and reduced claudication distance; reduced lower extremity strength and flexibility associated with physical inactivity; potential functional deficits in posture, balance, functional mobility, self-care performance, and gait mechanics; potential fall risk; potential overweight
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out  (3) Neurogenic causes –Herniated disc –Spinal stenosis (neurogenic claudication) –Peripheral radiculopathy DVT Popliteal entrapment syndrome(3) –Spinal stenosis –Medial tibial stress syndrome –Periostitis –Tibial stress fracture –Achilles tendinitis –Fibular stress fracture –Compartment syndrome (deep posterior, exertional, or recurrent anterior compartment syndrome) –Fascial hernia –Peripheral neuropathy (e.g., common peroneal nerve compression) –Venous stasis
prognosis: Natural progression of PAD includes gradual reduction in walking tolerance (e.g., 6MWT). However, only a minority of patients who receive optimal medical treatment experience severe leg pain at rest or require amputation(17,18,19) –The prognosis for motivated patients with isolated superficial femoral artery disease is excellent(19) –Among patients with IC:(17) -15–20%  will experience worsening claudication -5–10%  will undergo LE bypass surgery -2–5%  will require amputation (rates for patients with diabetes and those who smoke are much higher) –12% of patients with critical limb ischemia require amputation within 3 months of diagnosis. Patients with critical limb ischemia have a 9% mortality rate at 3 months after diagnosis and a 22% mortality rate at 1 year(3) –Mortality among patients with PAD can be as high as 50%(19)

Sedentary behavior and slow walking speed in the community are associated with faster functional decline and adverse changes in calf muscle(1) –Based on an observational study of 384 patients with ABI ≤0.90 who were followed for a median of 47 months –Patients with slower walking speed outside the home and/or greater hours sitting per day had greater declines in fast-paced  and usual-paced  4-meter  walking speed –Greater sedentary hours were also associated with a faster decline in calf muscle density (an indicator of muscle mass) measured by CT scans

Although good evidence has shown that medical management of PAD is effective in reducing mortality, symptoms, and complications, treatment of PAD in the Black population remains suboptimal, resulting in a high rate of disease and complications in this population(28)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Nutritionist for dietary modification and weight loss; wound care specialist and/or podiatrist as indicated for diabetic ulcers; occupational therapist for disability in ADLs; cardiac rehabilitation specialist; smoking cessation program It is recommended that the interdisciplinary care team for patients with CLI consist of vascular medical and surgical specialists, nurses, orthopedic surgeons and podiatrists, endocrinologists, internal medicine specialists, infectious disease specialists, radiologists, physical medicine and rehabilitation clinicians, orthotists and prosthetists, social workers, exercise physiologists, PTs and OTs, and nutritionists(16)
other considerations: Note whether patient has additional symptoms (e.g., foot pathology, arthritis, chest pain, shortness of breath) that interfere with or restrict the ability to exercise

A single session of high-voltage  galvanic stimulation (HVGS) or physical exercise was able to increase proximal blood circulation in women with diabetes and PAD, but only exercise was able to increase distal circulation(22)  –Based on a randomized crossover study of 15 women conducted in Brazil. Doppler ultrasound was used to measure circulation –HVGS parameters were 50 Hz frequency, twin pulses of 20 μs with 100 μsec interval between, maximum voltage tolerated by patient, 5 minute increments of synchronized stimulation (on 3 seconds, off 9 seconds), totaling 20 minutes of stimulation. The set-up  was four active electrodes set up as two channels and one dispersive electrode, where the two channels were placed on the anterior middle thigh and the triceps surae and the dispersive electrode on the lumbar region –Physical exercise consisted of active exercise in supine for the ankle (ankle pumps and circular motion) and 3 sets of 10 repetitions with 50%, 75%, 100% maximum resistance for the anterior and posterior muscles of the thigh and posterior muscles of the calf, with 5-minute  interval between sets –Continuous shortwave diathermy (capacitive method, moderate heat for 20 minutes) was also tested but was not found to affect blood circulation
treatment summary: Authors of a 2015 systematic review and meta-analysis  concluded that exercise training improved the mean difference of the following measures in patients with PAD:(20) –Peak VO 2 –6-minute  walk initial claudication –Total walking distance –Graded treadmill initial claudication –Absolute claudication distance –They also concluded that arm cranking and lower limb exercises in vigorous intensity intervals can be prescribed

The 2016 practice guidelines for the management of patients with PAD from the American College of Cardiology/ American Heart Association recommend supervised exercise training (treadmill or track walking, a minimum of 30 to 45 minutes, at least 3 times per week for a minimum of 12 weeks) as an initial treatment modality for patients with IC(16)

Researchers who conducted a prospective study in Poland found that 12 weeks of supervised treadmill walking training resulted in prolonged asymptomatic walking distance (as measured by MWT) as well as improved flow-mediated  dilation, indicating improved endothelial function(11)

Clinic-based  supervised exercise might be more effective for improving claudication distance than unsupervised or “go home and walk” exercise programs; however, researchers who conducted an RCT in the United States found that a 6-month group-mediated  cognitive behavioral (GMCB) intervention in which the participants performed home-based  walking exercises on their own resulted in increased improvement of the 6MWT and the WIQ over controls(14) –GMCB group attended weekly 90-minute  group support meetings that promoted exercise; the control group attended weekly lectures on topics unrelated to exercise –Benefits continued for the intervention group 12 months later, 6 months after the program ended

Authors of a Cochrane systematic review published in 2013 found a statistically significant benefit of supervised exercise therapy (SET) on treadmill walking distance (maximal and pain-free)  compared with non-supervised  regimens for patients with PAD(4)

Researchers in Brazil conducted a study on the effect of a single session of resistance exercise in patients with PAD and found the single session of resistance exercise increased blood flow and reactive hyperemia(23) –Resistance exercise consisted of 2 sets of 10 repetitions of 8 resistance exercises at a workload between 5 and 7 on the OMNI resistance exercise scale, with 2 minutes rest between sets and exercises

Authors of a 2017 systematic review concluded that individuals with PAD would benefit from a combined intervention of revascularization therapy and supervised exercise program compared to one of the interventions alone(24) –Based on a study in Australia that included eight trials with 726 patients (mean age 66 ± 3 years, ABI 0.66 ± 0.05) –Outcome measures used in these trials included the pain scales and maximal walking distance –Patients who were part of the combined therapy group had greater improvements in maximal walking distance and decreased levels of pain compared to those who received only supervised training or only revascularization . increased \u201cclaudication distance\u2: MWD, MWT, 6MWT, treadmill test, WIQ, WELCH
increased maximum walking distance: MWD, MWT, 6MWT, treadmill test, WIQ, WELCH
